<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Deforestation skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Deforestation</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
</p>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-protected&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-protected (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-protected</a><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bolivia-Deforestation-EO.JPG" title="File:Bolivia-Deforestation-EO.JPG">File:Bolivia-Deforestation-EO.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Satellite photograph of deforestation in progress in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tierras_Bajas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tierras Bajas (page does not exist)">Tierras Bajas</a> project in eastern <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><b>Deforestation</b>, <b>clearance</b> or <b>clearing</b> is the removal of a forest or stand of trees where the land is thereafter converted to a non-forest use.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Examples of deforestation include conversion of forestland to farms, ranches, or urban use.
</p><p>More than half of the animal and plant species in the world live in tropical forests.<sup id="cite_ref-Rainforest_Facts_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rainforest_Facts-2">[2]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Toc_left&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Toc left (page does not exist)">Template:Toc left</a>
</p><p>The term <i>deforestation</i> is often misused to describe any activity where all trees in an area are removed.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Failed_verification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Failed verification (page does not exist)">Template:Failed verification</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:POV-statement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:POV-statement (page does not exist)">Template:POV-statement</a> However in <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate climates</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Clear_cutting" title="Clear cutting" class="mw-redirect">removal of all trees in an area</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Failed_verification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Failed verification (page does not exist)">Template:Failed verification</a>—in conformance with <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_forestry" title="Sustainable forestry" class="mw-redirect">sustainable forestry</a> practices—is correctly described as <i>regeneration harvest</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Prairie#Mesic" title="Prairie">temperate mesic climates</a>, natural regeneration of forest stands often will not occur in the absence of disturbance, whether natural or anthropogenic.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> Furthermore, biodiversity after regeneration harvest often mimics that found after natural disturbance, including biodiversity loss after naturally occurring rainforest destruction.<sup id="cite_ref-SahneyBentonFalconLang_2010RainforestCollapse_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SahneyBentonFalconLang_2010RainforestCollapse-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Deforestation occurs for many reasons: trees are cut down to be used or sold as fuel (sometimes in the form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charcoal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charcoal (page does not exist)">charcoal</a>) or timber, while cleared land is used as <a href="/wiki/Pasture" title="Pasture">pasture</a> for livestock, plantations of commodities and settlements. The removal of trees without sufficient <a href="/wiki/Reforestation" title="Reforestation">reforestation</a> has resulted in damage to <a href="/wiki/Habitat" title="Habitat">habitat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a> loss and <a href="/wiki/Arid" title="Arid">aridity</a>. It has adverse impacts on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biosequestration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biosequestration (page does not exist)">biosequestration</a> of atmospheric <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a>. Deforestation has also been used in <a href="/wiki/War" title="War">war</a> to deprive an enemy of cover for its forces and also vital resources. A modern example of this was the use of <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a> by the United States military in Vietnam during the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>. Deforested regions typically incur significant adverse <a href="/wiki/Soil_erosion" title="Soil erosion" class="mw-redirect">soil erosion</a> and frequently degrade into <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wasteland" class="extiw" title="wikt:wasteland">wasteland</a>.
</p><p>Disregard or ignorance of intrinsic value, lack of ascribed value, lax forest management and deficient environmental laws are some of the factors that allow deforestation to occur on a large scale. In many countries, deforestation, both naturally occurring and human induced, is an ongoing issue. Deforestation causes <a href="/wiki/Extinction" title="Extinction">extinction</a>, changes to climatic conditions, <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">desertification</a>, and displacement of populations as observed by current conditions and in the past through the fossil record.<sup id="cite_ref-SahneyBentonFalconLang_2010RainforestCollapse_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SahneyBentonFalconLang_2010RainforestCollapse-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among countries with a per capita <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> of at least US$4,600, net deforestation rates have ceased to increase.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:When&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:When (page does not exist)">Template:When</a><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</li>
