</td>
<td> Africa
</td>
<td> 11%
</td>
<td> Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests<br /><a href="/wiki/Montane_grasslands_and_shrublands" title="Montane grasslands and shrublands">Montane grasslands and shrublands</a>
</td>
<td> Forests scattered along the eastern edge of Africa, from <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> in the north to <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a> in the south.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table></dd></dl>
<dl>
<dd><dl>
<dd>Table source:<sup id="cite_ref-ci2011_128-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ci2011-128">[128]</a></sup>
</dd>
</dl>
</dd>
</dl>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Control">Control</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reducing_emissions">Reducing emissions</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Main international organizations including the United Nations and the World Bank, have begun to develop programs aimed at curbing deforestation. The blanket term <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reducing_emissions_from_deforestation_and_forest_degradation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation (page does not exist)">Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation</a> (REDD) describes these sorts of programs, which use direct monetary or other incentives to encourage developing countries to limit and/or roll back deforestation. Funding has been an issue, but at the <a href="/wiki/UN_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change" title="UN Framework Convention on Climate Change" class="mw-redirect">UN Framework Convention on Climate Change</a> (UNFCCC) Conference of the Parties-15 (COP-15) in Copenhagen in December 2009, an accord was reached with a collective commitment by developed countries for new and additional resources, including forestry and investments through international institutions, that will approach USD 30 billion for the period 2010–2012.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Significant work is underway on tools for use in monitoring developing country adherence to their agreed REDD targets. These tools, which rely on remote forest monitoring using satellite imagery and other data sources, include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Center_for_Global_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Center for Global Development (page does not exist)">Center for Global Development's</a> FORMA (Forest Monitoring for Action) initiative <sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Group_on_Earth_Observations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Group on Earth Observations (page does not exist)"> Group on Earth Observations'</a> Forest Carbon Tracking Portal.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Methodological guidance for forest monitoring was also emphasized at COP-15.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> The environmental organization <a href="/w/index.php?title=Avoided_Deforestation_Partners&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Avoided Deforestation Partners (page does not exist)">Avoided Deforestation Partners</a> leads the campaign for development of REDD through funding from the U.S. government.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>In evaluating implications of overall emissions reductions, countries of greatest concern are those categorized as High Forest Cover with High Rates of Deforestation (HFHD) and Low Forest Cover with High Rates of Deforestation (LFHD). Afghanistan, Benin, Botswana, Burma, Burundi, Cameroon, Chad, Ecuador, El Salvador, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guatemala, Guinea, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deforestation_in_Haiti&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deforestation in Haiti (page does not exist)">Haiti</a>, Honduras, Indonesia, Liberia, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mongolia, Namibia, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Pakistan, Paraguay, Philippines, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Togo, Uganda, United Republic of Tanzania, Zimbabwe are listed as having Low Forest Cover with High Rates of Deforestation (LFHD). Brazil, Cambodia, Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea, Equatorial Guinea, Malaysia, Solomon Islands, Timor-Leste, Venezuela, Zambia are listed as High Forest Cover with High Rates of Deforestation (HFHD).<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Payments_for_conserving_forests">Payments for conserving forests</span></h4>
<p>In Bolivia, deforestation in upper river basins has caused environmental problems, including soil erosion and declining water quality. An innovative project to try and remedy this situation involves landholders in upstream areas being paid by downstream water users to conserve forests. The landholders receive US$20 to conserve the trees, avoid polluting livestock practices, and enhance the biodiversity and forest carbon on their land. They also receive US$30, which purchases a beehive, to compensate for conservation for two hectares of water-sustaining forest for five years. Honey revenue per hectare of forest is US$5 per year, so within five years, the landholder has sold US$50 of honey.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> The project is being conducted by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundaci%C3%B3n_Natura_Bolivia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fundación Natura Bolivia (page does not exist)">Fundación Natura Bolivia</a> and Rare Conservation, with support from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Climate_%26_Development_Knowledge_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Climate &amp; Development Knowledge Network (page does not exist)">Climate &amp; Development Knowledge Network</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Farming">Farming</span></h3>
<p>New methods are being developed to farm more intensively, such as high-yield <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)">hybrid</a> crops, <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse" title="Greenhouse">greenhouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_building" title="Autonomous building">autonomous building</a> gardens, and <a href="/wiki/Hydroponic" title="Hydroponic" class="mw-redirect">hydroponics</a>. These methods are often dependent on chemical inputs to maintain necessary yields. In cyclic <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, cattle are grazed on farm land that is resting and rejuvenating. Cyclic agriculture actually increases the fertility of the soil. Intensive farming can also decrease soil nutrients by consuming at an accelerated rate the trace minerals needed for crop growth.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}The most promising approach, however, is the concept of <a href="/wiki/Forest_gardening" title="Forest gardening">food forests</a> in <a href="/wiki/Permaculture" title="Permaculture">permaculture</a>, which consists of agroforestal systems carefully designed to mimic natural forests, with an emphasis on plant and animal species of interest for food, timber and other uses. These systems have low dependence on <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuels" title="Fossil fuels" class="mw-redirect">fossil fuels</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agro-chemicals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agro-chemicals (page does not exist)">agro-chemicals</a>, are highly self-maintaining, highly productive, and with strong positive impact on soil and water quality, and <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monitoring_deforestation">Monitoring deforestation</span></h3>
<p>There are multiple methods that are appropriate and reliable for reducing and monitoring deforestation. One method is the “visual interpretation of aerial photos or satellite imagery that is labor-intensive but does not require high-level training in computer image processing or extensive computational resources”.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-76">[76]</a></sup> Another method includes hot-spot analysis (that is, locations of rapid change) using expert opinion or coarse resolution satellite data to identify locations for detailed digital analysis with high resolution satellite images.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_76-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-76">[76]</a></sup> Deforestation is typically assessed by quantifying the amount of area deforested, measured at the present time.
From an environmental point of view, quantifying the damage and its possible consequences is a more important task, while conservation efforts are more focused on forested land protection and development of land-use alternatives to avoid continued deforestation.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_76-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-76">[76]</a></sup> Deforestation rate and total area deforested, have been widely used for monitoring deforestation in many regions, including the Brazilian Amazon deforestation monitoring by INPE.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-45">[45]</a></sup> Monitoring deforestation is a very complicated process, which becomes even more complicated with the increasing needs for resources.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Forest_management">Forest management</span></h3>
<p>Efforts to stop or slow deforestation have been attempted for many centuries because it has long been known that deforestation can cause environmental damage sufficient in some cases to cause societies to collapse. In <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>, paramount rulers developed policies designed to prevent conflicts between short-term gains from converting forest to farmland and long-term problems forest loss would cause,<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> while during the 17th and 18th centuries in <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate" title="Tokugawa shogunate">Tokugawa</a>, Japan,<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> the shoguns developed a highly sophisticated system of long-term planning to stop and even reverse deforestation of the preceding centuries through substituting timber by other products and more efficient use of land that had been farmed for many centuries. In 16th-century Germany, landowners also developed <a href="/wiki/Silviculture" title="Silviculture">silviculture</a> to deal with the problem of deforestation. However, these policies tend to be limited to environments with <i>good rainfall</i>, <i>no dry season</i> and <i>very young <a href="/wiki/Soil" title="Soil">soils</a></i> (through <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcanism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Glaciation" title="Glaciation" class="mw-redirect">glaciation</a>). This is because on older and less fertile soils trees grow too slowly for silviculture to be economic, whilst in areas with a strong dry season there is always a risk of forest fires destroying a tree crop before it matures.
</p><p>In the areas where "<a href="/wiki/Slash-and-burn" title="Slash-and-burn">slash-and-burn</a>" is practiced, switching to "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Slash-and-char&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slash-and-char (page does not exist)">slash-and-char</a>" would prevent the rapid deforestation and subsequent degradation of soils. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biochar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biochar (page does not exist)">biochar</a> thus created, given back to the soil, is not only a durable <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_sequestration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon sequestration (page does not exist)">carbon sequestration</a> method, but it also is an extremely beneficial <a href="/wiki/Soil_conditioner" title="Soil conditioner">amendment</a> to the soil. Mixed with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biomass&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biomass (page does not exist)">biomass</a> it brings the creation of <a href="/wiki/Terra_preta" title="Terra preta">terra preta</a>, one of the richest soils on the planet and the only one known to regenerate itself.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Sustainable_practices">Sustainable practices</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bamboo_Feb09.jpg" title="File:Bamboo Feb09.jpg">File:Bamboo Feb09.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Bamboo is advocated as a more sustainable alternative for cutting down wood for fuel.<sup id="cite_ref-bamboo_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bamboo-148">[148]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Certification, as provided by global certification systems such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Programme_for_the_Endorsement_of_Forest_Certification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (page does not exist)">Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification</a> and <a href="/wiki/Forest_Stewardship_Council" title="Forest Stewardship Council">Forest Stewardship Council</a>, contributes to tackling deforestation by creating market demand for timber from sustainably managed forests. According to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), "A major condition for the adoption of sustainable forest management is a demand for products that are produced sustainably and consumer willingness to pay for the higher costs entailed. Certification represents a shift from regulatory approaches to market incentives to promote sustainable forest management. By promoting the positive attributes of forest products from sustainably managed forests, certification focuses on the demand side of environmental conservation."<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rettet_den_Regenwald&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rettet den Regenwald (page does not exist)">Rainforest Rescue</a> argues that the standards of organizations like FSC are too closely connected to industry interests and therefore do not guarantee environmentally and socially responsible forest management. In reality, monitoring systems are inadequate and various cases of fraud have been documented worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some nations have taken steps to help increase the amount of trees on Earth. In 1981, China created National Tree Planting Day Forest and forest coverage had now reached 16.55% of China's land mass, as against only 12% two decades ago <sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Using fuel from <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a> rather than wood results in cleaner burning, and since bamboo matures much faster than wood, deforestation is reduced as supply can be replenished faster.<sup id="cite_ref-bamboo_148-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bamboo-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reforestation">Reforestation</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In many parts of the world, especially in East Asian countries, reforestation and <a href="/wiki/Afforestation" title="Afforestation">afforestation</a> are increasing the area of forested lands.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> The amount of woodland has increased in 22 of the world's 50 most forested nations. Asia as a whole gained 1 million <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hectare&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hectare (page does not exist)">hectares</a> of forest between 2000 and 2005. Tropical forest in El Salvador expanded more than 20% between 1992 and 2001. Based on these trends, one study projects that global forest will increase by 10%—an area the size of India—by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-news.nationalgeographic.com_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news.nationalgeographic.com-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">People's Republic of China</a>, where large scale destruction of forests has occurred, the government has in the past required that every able-bodied citizen between the ages of 11 and 60 plant three to five trees per year or do the equivalent amount of work in other forest services. The government claims that at least 1 <a href="/w/index.php?title=1000000000_(number)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1000000000 (number) (page does not exist)">billion</a> trees have been planted in China every year since 1982. This is no longer required today, but March 12 of every year in China is the Planting Holiday. Also, it has introduced the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Green_Wall_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Green Wall of China (page does not exist)">Green Wall of China</a> project, which aims to halt the expansion of the Gobi desert through the planting of trees. However, due to the large percentage of trees dying off after planting (up to 75%), the project is not very successful.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} There has been a 47-million-hectare increase in forest area in China since the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-news.nationalgeographic.com_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news.nationalgeographic.com-153">[153]</a></sup> The total number of trees amounted to be about 35 billion and 4.55% of China's land mass increased in forest coverage. The forest coverage was 12% two decades ago and now is 16.55%.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>An ambitious proposal for China is the Aerially Delivered Re-forestation and Erosion Control System and the proposed Sahara Forest Project coupled with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seawater_Greenhouse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seawater Greenhouse (page does not exist)">Seawater Greenhouse</a>.
</p><p>In Western countries, increasing consumer demand for wood products that have been produced and harvested in a sustainable manner is causing forest landowners and forest industries to become increasingly accountable for their forest management and timber harvesting practices.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Arbor_Day_Foundation" title="Arbor Day Foundation">Arbor Day Foundation</a>'s Rain Forest Rescue program is a charity that helps to prevent deforestation. The charity uses donated money to buy up and preserve rainforest land before the <a href="/wiki/Lumber" title="Lumber">lumber</a> companies can buy it. The Arbor Day Foundation then protects the land from deforestation. This also locks in the way of life of the primitive tribes living on the forest land. Organizations such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Community_Forestry_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Community Forestry International (page does not exist)">Community Forestry International</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cool_Earth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cool Earth (page does not exist)">Cool Earth</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Nature_Conservancy" title="The Nature Conservancy">The Nature Conservancy</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Wide Fund for Nature (page does not exist)">World Wide Fund for Nature</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Conservation_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Conservation International (page does not exist)">Conservation International</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_Conservation_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African Conservation Foundation (page does not exist)">African Conservation Foundation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace" title="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a> also focus on preserving forest habitats. Greenpeace in particular has also mapped out the forests that are still intact<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> and published this information on the internet.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> World Resources Institute in turn has made a simpler thematic map<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> showing the amount of forests present just before the age of man (8000 years ago) and the current (reduced) levels of forest.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> These maps mark the amount of afforestation required to repair the damage caused by people.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Forest_plantations">Forest plantations</span></h3>
<p>To meet the world's demand for wood, it has been suggested by forestry writers Botkins and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sedjo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sedjo (page does not exist)">Sedjo</a> that high-yielding forest <a href="/wiki/Plantations" title="Plantations" class="mw-redirect">plantations</a> are suitable. It has been calculated that plantations yielding 10 cubic meters per hectare annually could supply all the timber required for international trade on 5% of the world's existing forestland. By contrast, natural forests produce about 1–2 cubic meters per hectare; therefore, 5–10 times more forestland would be required to meet demand. Forester Chad Oliver has suggested a forest mosaic with high-yield forest lands interpersed with conservation land.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the country of Senegal, on the western coast of Africa, a movement headed by youths has helped to plant over 6 million mangrove trees. The trees will protect local villages from storm damages and will provide a habitat for local wildlife. The project started in 2008, and already the Senegalese government has been asked to establish rules and regulations that would protect the new mangrove forests.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_context">Military context</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Attack_on_bloody_ridge.jpg" title="File:Attack on bloody ridge.jpg">File:Attack on bloody ridge.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">American <a href="/wiki/M4_Sherman" title="M4 Sherman">Sherman tanks</a> knocked out by Japanese artillery on Okinawa.</div></div></div>While the preponderance of deforestation is due to demands for agricultural and urban use for the human population, there are some examples of military causes. One example of deliberate deforestation is that which took place in the U.S. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Allied_Occupation_Zones_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allied Occupation Zones in Germany (page does not exist)">zone of occupation</a> in Germany after World War II. Before the onset of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, defeated Germany was still considered a potential future threat rather than potential future ally. To address this threat, attempts were made to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Industrial_plans_for_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Industrial plans for Germany (page does not exist)">lower German industrial potential</a>, of which forests were deemed an element. Sources in the U.S. government admitted that the purpose of this was that the "ultimate destruction of the war potential of German forests." As a consequence of the practice of clear-felling, deforestation resulted which could "be replaced only by long forestry development over perhaps a century."<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
<p><a href="/wiki/War" title="War">War</a> can also be a cause of deforestation, either deliberately such as through the use of <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> during the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> where, together with bombs and bulldozers, it contributed to the destruction of 44% of the forest cover,<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> or inadvertently such as in the 1945 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Okinawa" title="Battle of Okinawa">Battle of Okinawa</a> where bombardment and other combat operations reduced the lush tropical landscape into "a vast field of mud, lead, decay and maggots".<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>

</p>

</li>

<dl>
<dt>In the media
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>March 14, 2007, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Independent" title="The Independent">Independent Online</a></i>: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.independent.co.uk/environment/article2355962.ece">Destruction of forests in developing world 'out of control'</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_web&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite web (page does not exist)">Template:Cite web</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Films online
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>Watch the <a href="/wiki/National_Film_Board_of_Canada" title="National Film Board of Canada">National Film Board of Canada</a> documentaries <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nfb.ca/film/battle_for_the_trees/"><i>Battle for the Trees</i></a> &amp; <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nfb.ca/film/forest_in_crisis/"><i>Forest in Crisis</i></a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://indigenouspeoplesissues.com/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=4668:video-on-deforestation-in-paraguay-as-a-result-of-agricultural-development-impact-to-indigenous-people-and-wildlife&amp;catid=68:videos-and-movies&amp;Itemid=96">Video on Illegal Deforestation In Paraguay</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Deforestation_and_desertification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Deforestation and desertification (page does not exist)">Template:Deforestation and desertification</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Deforestation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Deforestation (page does not exist)">Template:Deforestation</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Human_impact_on_the_environment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Human impact on the environment (page does not exist)">Template:Human impact on the environment</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Link_FA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Link FA (page does not exist)">Template:Link FA</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Link_FA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Link FA (page does not exist)">Template:Link FA</a>
<br /><strong class="error mw-ext-cite-error">Cite error: <code>&lt;ref&gt;</code> tags exist, but no <code>&lt;references/&gt;</code> tag was found</strong>
</p>
